subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
In the oracle bone script, it is an {{Han compound|卩|䇂|nocap=1|ls=ic|t1=kneeling person|t2=sickle-like tool}} – to administer; to regulate; to punish.

{{zh-l|*〇}} was sometimes added, though its function is disputed:
* {{zh-ref|Lin (1920)}} suggests that it represents “bind; restrain”.
* {{zh-ref|Luo (1927)}} suggests that it is the original character for {{och-l|璧|jade annulus}} and that {{zh-l|*辟}} is the early form of {{zh-l|*璧}}, with {{zh-l|*〇}} as the semantic component and {{lang|zh|⿰卩䇂}} as the phonetic component. {{zh-ref|Chi (2010)}}, based on this theory, proposes that {{zh-l|*〇}} acted as a phonetic component in {{lang|zh|辟}} instead.
* {{zh-ref|Yu (1999)}} suggests that it is a decorative component with no meaning.
{{zh-l|*〇}} was later corrupted into {{zh-l|*口}} or {{zh-l|*日}}. ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' interprets {{zh-l|*口}} as representing the enforcer of the law.

In the bronze script from the {{w|Warring States period}}, forms where {{zh-l|*䇂}} is corrupted to {{zh-l|*辛}} begin to appear ({{zh-ref|Chi, 2010}}).

Officially adopted as the simplified form of {{zh-l|*闢}} in the ''Chinese Character Simplification Scheme'' ({{w2|zh|pref=《|s:漢字簡化方案|漢字簡化方案|suf=》}}) in 1956 due to homophony and shared semantic fields.
